Consider Sparta, the ancient Greek city-state that organized its entire society around militarization, with a highly stratified structure based on tiers of citizenship and slavery. At its zenith, Sparta was incredibly successful, yet it refused to evolve and adapt, ultimately falling to the more flexible and innovative tactics of the democratic Theban Confederation in the Battle of Leuctra. Thus, the society that permitted greater flexibility and innovation triumphed over the one that was overly focused on warfare and deluded by its own inflexible superiority.
